labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

labels.name: wontfix
labels.description: This will not be worked on

issues.title: Security Consideration: FIPS Mode
issues.author: hannestschofenig
issues.body:
Time at which the attester collected information from the target environment(s) is important with regards to the properties included in the cert. 

For example, a device may obtain a certificate from a CA after it was booted in FIPS mode. Then, the device reboots in non-FIPS mode. 

Likely implementation: FIPS mode changes are destructive, which means that the certificate and the private key will get deleted. The device will have to obtain a new certificate.

issues.title: We need a section on AK restrictions
issues.author: ounsworth
issues.body:
At the minimum, we need a non-normative section describing the properties that an AK key MUST have. Things like:

* Only ever signs attestation objects (ie cannot be a signing fool).
* Is either injected and certified at manufacture time and chains to a vendor manufacture root, or else is injected at network onboarding time and chains to a network operator root.

Discussion point: should we, in this specification, be prescriptive about the structure of an AK certificate (ie prescribing v3 extensions that it must have), or should we describe non-normatively the properties that this should have, and then leave this to be vendor-specific?
(I think the HSM vendors would prefer flexibility here)

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body:
> * Is either injected and certified at manufacture time and chains to a vendor manufacture root, or else is injected at network onboarding time and chains to a network operator root.

Is this to say that an attestation signing key can't be generated within the HSM? Some customers prefer this over having to trust a vendor's key injection process (which they can't easily audit).

comments.author: ounsworth
comments.body:
> > * Is either injected and certified at manufacture time and chains to a vendor manufacture root, or else is injected at network onboarding time and chains to a network operator root.
> 
> Is this to say that an attestation signing key can't be generated within the HSM? Some customers prefer this over having to trust a vendor's key injection process (which they can't easily audit).

Sorry, I meant to say that the AK _certificate_ is injected at network onboarding time; ie the device would do a CSR to a CA run by its new owner, for an AK generated internally to the device.

issues.title: We need a section on Root-of-Trust endorsements
issues.author: ounsworth
issues.body:
I the "big HSM" world, you fully trust the entirety of the hardware boundary because it has been validated by FIPS CMVP, or Common Criteria. This is an "endorsement" in RATS terminology, but may not come in an automated format; ie a human may have to take the hardware_oem, hardware_model, and sw_version claims from the evidence and go find that thing on the NIST CMVP website.

This should be described in the document.

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body:
The endorsement document could be a certificate which binds an instance identifier (public key) to a device type or model (these are class identifiers). 

Then endorsement document for a CC or FIPS certified entity is a class identifier that binds the class of device with a rating. 

If the class identifiers between the two documents are the same type. Then a verifier can relate the two documents even if they have difrerent signers and different lifecycles.

issues.title: Should we flip the order of nesting?
issues.author: ounsworth
issues.body:
Mike's samples have the KAT claims is the inner signed objects, and then are placed within an outer PAT signed object. From an HSM perspective, this makes sense. But from a RATS / DICE perspective it usually goes the other way where lower-level platforms (ex.: secure boot) produces its signed statement, and then this is included in a higher-level signed statement (ex.: OS boot)

Should we flip the order?

Do we actually need to do prescriptive about this, or we do only need to define a flexible syntax and then let HSM vendors use it either way?

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body:
> But from a RATS / DICE perspective

I disagree. RATS doesn't equate nesting with idenitity. DICE keys are derived from environmental attributes, but once an identifier is generated, it doesn't NEED to be nested for it to make sense. 
Having globally unique identfiers for environments means you don't depend on nesting (local name space scoping) contexts for disambiguation. A flat list of tuples : (environment identifier, attribute value) offers sufficient disambiguation if _environment identifier_ is globally unique. 

I'm not asking you to go look, but if you don't believe me you can look at the internal representation of claims in the corim draft which is modeled as a flat list of claims.

Given attestation pretty much requires attestation keys to assert claims, keys can be a reasonable instance specific identifiers for environments. This is what a device cert is doing already. It's often helpful to have a class specific identifier for cases where an attribute applies to multiple devices/environments at the same time (such as a model or versioned thing). If the class identifiers are also globally unique, then they don't depend on nesting for disambiguation. A key can also be a class identifier if it is a group key. 

HSMs are not different from other embedded computing environments in that they have both class-based and instance-based objects for which it makes sense to produce attested claims that describes them. If I have a preference, it is that the objects be identified with globally unique identifiers to minimize the need for composite nested identifiers.

comments.author: ounsworth
comments.body: No longer applies since we now have no nesting.

issues.title: Declare trust relationships between Attester and Verifier out-of-scope
issues.author: henkbirkholz
issues.body: This would be easiest accomplished,I think, by stating that [Section 7.4](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9334.html#section-7.4) of [RFC9334](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9334.html) does not apply in this document.

issues.title: Declaring Attester and Attesting Environment as interchangeable term
issues.author: henkbirkholz
issues.body: In order to avoid confusion about nesting and cardinality of environments, I'd like to propose to limit the numbers of Attesting Environments per Attester to one. That way the terms automatically become interchangeable.

comments.author: ounsworth
comments.body: We now have a concept of "Attestation Service", which is made clear by the architecture diagram.

issues.title: Format of the public key
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
Currently, `pub-key` is `OCTET STRING` in ASN.1 and `bstr` in CBOR.

Two observations:

1. There is no equivalent JSON type, which EAT requires.  (But this seems to be a general problem with the EAT claims.)
2. The claim is untyped.  The document should be clear about what type of public key is expected (`SubjectPublicKeyInfo`, `COSE_Key`, `JWK`, etc.).

comments.author: ounsworth
comments.body: It will be `SubjectPublicKeyInfo`, and the new version makes this clear. This draft does not provide any CBOR or JOSE encoding, so I think I can close this issue.

issues.title: There is no such thing as "self-attested evidence"
issues.author: henkbirkholz
issues.body: Maybe I am missing something super obvious - so please correct me, if I am wrong, but either pick "signed self-assertion" or "evidence" (as evidence shall be specified by some source, maybe RATS). Self-attested evidence reads like a paradox to me.

comments.author: ounsworth
comments.body:
The sentence in question is now:

> The data format in this specification represents self-attested evidence and therefore requires third-party endorsement in order to establish trust.

Is "self-attested evidence" a paradox (contradiction) or redundant?

In the same way that this draft must over-explain PKI and HSM concepts for a RATS audience, I think it is ok to over-explain RATS concepts to a PKI and HSM audience.

issues.title: An EAT is a CWT
issues.author: henkbirkholz
issues.body:
> JWT "iat"  The time at which this token was generated. EDNOTE: Surely such a thing already exists in EAT?

Yes, the IAT Claim is specified inf [RFC 7519](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7519) and in [RFC 8392](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8392) respectively.

issues.title: If Platform and Transaction Entities can only appear once, then why not make them explicitly part of the TBS struct?
issues.author: ounsworth
issues.body:
It seems like it's adding complexity to make Platform Entities and Transaction Entities part of the Entity list, and then in text restrict them to "_MAY contain only one"._

In this case, wouldn't it be better to do this so that this constraint can be enforced by the ASN.1 parser?

```
TbsPkixAttestation ::= SEQUENCE {
    version INTEGER,
    reportedEntities SEQUENCE SIZE (1..MAX) OF ReportedEntity,
    platformEntity        OPTIONAL [0] PlatformEntity,
    transactionEntity    OPTIONAL [1] TransactionEntity
}
```

We can use the fancy new ASN.1 syntax .&Type({AttrSet}{@type} -- or whatever -- to restrict the valid types for ReportedEntity, and in this document we only register KeyEntity as a valid type for ReportedEntity.

issues.title: TODO: Pre-122 edits
issues.author: ounsworth
issues.body:
- aasvg should be HSM?
- asn.1 extensions markers on the extensible structures?
- Be careful about MUSTs in the request section
- broken link {#sec-cons-privacy}
- Think about moving the Request stuff to its own section at the end.
- take out the asciiString and just make utf8String
- Comments from Richard
  - add a fipslevel pa


From Richard:

> A PKIX Attestation containing more than one platform entity is considered a fatal error by a parser

Can we make this into a MUST statement about parsers?


> A PKIX Attestation can contain at most one transaction entity

Here too.


> fipsboot

There's some structure to FIPS compliance:
standard version (present FIPS 140-3 but could be others in the future)
level
Do we want to express any of that?



> Corresponds directly to PKCS#11 CKA_EXTRACTABLE.

CKA_EXTRACTABLE means wrappable. But we need to take into account CKA_SENSITIVE too. For example a key with CKA_EXTRACTABLE=false, CKA_SENSITIVE=false could be read out of an HSM simply by calling C_GetAttributeValue. 

So I think we need to define the property here a bit differently. For attestation purposes you mostly want to know if the key cannot be extracted from the HSM in any form (i.e. wrapped or plaintext).

(I guess someone might be interested in "can be wrapped but no plaintext export" but that opens a rather large can of worms about what key(s) and mechanism(s) can be used to wrap it. Let's not.)

MikeO: For now I'll just add an EDNOTE for future design team discussion.

issues.title: How to use the format with the CSR Attestation Draft
issues.author: hannestschofenig
issues.body:
It is unclear to me how I would use the structure with a CSR attestation draft where I can only proof possession of a single application key and that proof of possessoin is actually part of the signature computed over the CSR itself.

Would therefore the application private key proof of possession happen twice - once for the CSR and then again for the structure defined in the draft or does the structure in the draft only get signed by the attestation key.

This part is not clear for me from reading the spec.

issues.title: repo name change needed?
issues.author: nedmsmith
issues.body: Given the name of the draft changed to include pkix, should the repo name be updated as well to disambiguate from prior naming?

issues.title: s/Attestation Message/PKIX Evidence
issues.author: hannestschofenig

issues.title: References to TPM could be dropped
issues.author: bluegate010
issues.body:
The specification makes two references to TPMs:

> For relatively simple HSM devices such as TPM-like devices, storage properties such as "extractable" may always be true for all keys since the devices are not capable of key export and so the attestation could be essentially a hard-coded template asserting these immutable attributes. However, more complex HSM devices require a more complex key attestation format that encompasses the mutability of these attributes.

> "Often, a TPM will host cryptographic keys for both the kernel and userspace of a local operating system, but a Presenter may only represent a single user or application."

These references could safely be dropped, as this specification is targeting HSMs, not TPMs.

(Also, "'extractable' may always be true" seems to disagree with "the devices are not capable of key export".)

issues.title: 'Entity' term is not self-describing
issues.author: bluegate010

issues.title: Add support for multi-signature key binding
issues.author: bluegate010
issues.body:
The specification currently states:

> This design also does not prevent against stripping attacks where an attacker removes a signature without leaving evidence in the message that an additional signature had been there or signature re-ordering attacks. Again, this is left up to Verifier policy to know how many algorithms or counter-signatures it is expecting.

We could extend the transaction entity attributes table with the following:

| Attribute         | AttributeValue  | Reference   | Multiple? | OID                                              |
| ---               | ---             | ---         | ---       | ---                                              |
| ak-spki | bytes | {{&SELF}} | Yes        | id-pkix-evidence-attribute-transaction-ak-spki  |

This attribute would contain the `spki` for each Attestation Key that the HSM intends to use to sign the claims.

issues.title: "Signature re-ordering attack" is undefined
issues.author: bluegate010
issues.body:
The specification currently states:

> This design also does not prevent against stripping attacks where an attacker removes a signature without leaving evidence in the message that an additional signature had been there or signature re-ordering attacks. Again, this is left up to Verifier policy to know how many algorithms or counter-signatures it is expecting.

It is unclear what a "signature re-ordering attack" is. We could drop this and simply state that attackers are free to remove or re-order signatures at will.

issues.title: Feature request: usermod digest attestation
issues.author: bluegate010
issues.body:
The spec currently defines a `usermod` platform entity attribute:

> Most HSMs have some concept of trusted execution environment where user software modules can be loaded inside the HSM to run with some level of privileged access to the application keys. This attribute lists user modules currently loaded onto the HSM in a human readable format, preferably JSON.

It would be nice to define a standard format for reporting the usermod version and digest. That may be outside the scope of this particular specification though.

issues.title: Contradiction on whether multiple key entities can refer to the same cryptographic keypair
issues.author: bluegate010
issues.body:
The spec states:

> A key entity is associated with the type `id-pkix-attest-entity-key`. Each instance of a key entity represents a different cryptographic key found in the Target Environment. There can be multiple key entities found in a claim description, but each reported key entity MUST describe a different cryptographic key.

And,

> A Verifier that encounters a claim description with multiple key entities referring to the same cryptographic key MUST reject the Evidence.

However, earlier the spec states:

> For example, if a given application public key appears in two different entities, these MUST be interpreted as two distinct and independent entities that happen to have the same public key, and MUST NOT be interpreted as adding additional attributes to the already-described entity.

issues.title: Unclear purpose of the 'protection' key entity attribute type
issues.author: bluegate010
issues.body:
The `protection` attribute type "indicates any additional key protection properties around use or modification of this key. These are generalized properties and will not apply the same way to all HSM vendors. Consult vendor documentation for the in-context meaning of these flags."

There are indications that this will be defined as an extensible byte array.

It seems that we could simply allow these "additional key protection properties" to be defined in terms of future OIDs rather than a bitfield, which is the extension mechanism that the spec uses for entity and attribute types generally.

issues.title: Minor: content duplicated across Signing Procedure and Verifying Procedure
issues.author: bluegate010
issues.body:
The Signing Procedure section has the following content:

> The `SignatureBlock.signatureValue` signs over the DER-encoded to-be-signed attestation data `PkixEvidence.tbs` and MUST be validated with the subject public key of the leaf X.509 certificate contained in the `SignatureBlock.certChain`.

This is duplicated in the Verifying Procedure section just below. These could potentially be deduped and instead of separate sections, just retitle to "Signing and Verifying Procedure".

issues.title: Spec uses potentially problematic language
issues.author: bluegate010
issues.body:
The spec currently states:

> Since HSMs are generally servers (client/server relationship) or slaves (master/slave relationship)

We could potentially modify this to state:

> Since HSMs are generally servers (client/server relationship) or peripherals (controller/peripheral relationship)

issues.title: The "Architecture" figure depicts separate Attesting and Target environments
issues.author: bluegate010
issues.body:
Early on the spec states that "this specification assumes that the Attesting Environment and the Target Environment, as outlined in {{!RFC9334}}, are the same."

The [Architecture diagram](https://github.com/ietf-rats-wg/key-attestation/blob/bfba6f50dabc8ff69d35175b69ae50792648cc67/draft-ietf-rats-pkix-key-attestation.md?plain=1#L915-L944) depicts them as separate. Should it unify them?

issues.title: Minor: unclear language in the Attestation Requests section
issues.author: bluegate010
issues.body:
The spec states: (emphasis added)

> In most cases the value of a request attribute should be left unspecified by the Presenter. In the process of generating the evidence, the values of the desired attributes are observed by the attestation service within the HSM and reported accordingly. For the purpose of creating a request, the Presenter sets the values of the attributes to `null`. **This is a departure from the values specified for each attribute** but serves well the purposes of the request.

Is the bolded portion simply noting that the attested values will differ from the requested values? Or something else?

issues.title: Unclear purpose behind supporting multiple attested nonces
issues.author: bluegate010
issues.body:
The `nonce` attribute is repeatable in the Transaction entity:

> The attribute "nonce" is used to provide "freshness" quality as to the claims provided in the PkixEvidence message. A Presenter requesting a PkixEvidence message MAY provide a nonce value as part of the request. This nonce value, if provided, SHOULD be repeated as an attribute within the transaction entity.
> 
> This is similar to the attribute "eat_nonce" as defined in {{!RFC9711}}. According to this specification, this attribute may be specified multiple times with different values. In that case, all different values shall be repeated in the PKIXEvidence.


In the non-normative Attestation Requests section, the nonce is described thusly:

> A Presenter may choose to include a nonce as part of the attestation request. When producing the PKIX evidence, the HSM repeats the nonce that was provided as part of the request.
> 
> When providing a nonce, a Presenter includes, in the attestation request, an entity of type `id-pkix-evidence-entity-transaction` with an attribute of type `id-pkix-evidence-attribute-transaction-nonce`. This attribute is set with the value of the nonce as "bytes".

It is unclear based on the cited language why multiple nonces are supported. It could be worth including an example that illustrates when multiple nonces would be used.

issues.title: Contradiction on whether an unrecognized request attribute must be rejected
issues.author: bluegate010
issues.body:
The spec has the following two pieces of language, which contradict each other:

> An Attester (HSM) which is requested to provide information about unrecognized Entity or Attribute types MUST fail the operation.

> An Attester SHOULD fail an attestation request if it contains a request attribute with an unrecognized type.

issues.title: Feature request: DICE-based Attestation Keys
issues.author: bluegate010
issues.body:
The specification defines the Attestation Key as the key which signs evidence. The specification allows, but does not make explicit, that the Attestation Key may be part of a DICE hierarchy.

It would be useful to describe this, which would be a valuable feature for customers wishing to obtain strong attestation that their HSMs are running a given firmware version.

pulls.title: Editorial suggestions on the introductory parts
pulls.author: frumioj

comments.author: hannestschofenig
comments.body: Thanks for the input, John. I would like to merge the PR

pulls.title: Provide new sample code
pulls.author: jpfiset
pulls.body: Added "idea3" in the sample code. This demonstrates the use of "entities" and "attributes". With this approach, there is a flat list of entities in the top "to-be-signed" structure. Each entity contains a flat list of attributes.

pulls.author: hannestschofenig
pulls.body: Attempt to clean up the terminology section

pulls.title: Figure fix
pulls.author: hannestschofenig
pulls.body: .... the application key (which I called the Identity Key) is not mentioned in the RATS architecture since it relates to key attestation.

pulls.title: misc changes to get idnits to be quiet
pulls.author: nedmsmith
pulls.body:
Some of these are benign changes. The street on line 34 seems like the main culprit. There were also errors due to unreferenced references. Added reference tags for simpler citing within the doc.

Added .txt file to gitignore.

There are still a ton of idnits due to lines that are too long. Not sure if there's away to fix this.

pulls.title: Update draft-ounsworth-rats-pkix-key-attestation.md
pulls.author: nedmsmith
pulls.body: fixed warning using name: in reference twice.

pulls.title: Adding Figure to Attestation Request Section
pulls.author: hannestschofenig

pulls.title: Miscellaneous editorial fixes.
pulls.author: bluegate010
pulls.body:
- Spelling/grammar fixes

- Remove "you" language

- s/judicial/judicious/, to avoid legal connotations

- Minor clarification around the role of Presenter; "join" may be taken to mean that it is a hybrid role consisting of both the Attester and Verifier.

- Use "Target Environment" consistently, instead of a mix of that and "Attesting Environment"

- s/should be extensible/is extensible/, to describe the state of the specification, rather than its goals.

- Attributes don't have both a type and an attribute type, dropped the former.

- Consistent capitalization of SHOULD NOT

- Target environments which use out-of-band mechanisms for communicating the AK are not automatically non-compliant, as long as they also use a compliant mechanism for communicating the AK.

- Oxford comma usage

- "relating to the related" - dropped the latter

- "The following table lists the attributes for a key entity (key attributes)" - 'key attributes' is not used elsewhere, can drop the parenthetical.

- "A transaction entity, if provided, should be included only once" - upgraded 'should' to 'must', since verifiers 'must' reject if multiple are found.

- "The following table lists the attributes for a transaction entity (transaction attributes)" - for simplicity we can just use 'transaction entity attributes' in the couple places it's referred to, and avoid the parenthetical.

- "Multiple of these cases, and potentially others, could be present in a single PkixEvidence object." - changed to "supported by" a single PkixEvidence object, since the object contains ASN.1.

- Consistent hyphenation of "third-party"

- "These appraisal profiles" - 'appraisal profile' is undefined, we can just use 'appraisal policy profile'

- "Since HSMs are generally servers or slaves, an entity is required" - 'entity' is already defined, changed to "Presenter"

- s/TbsPkixEvidence/ClaimDescriptionTbs/, since the former is not defined.

- Add reference to sec-cons-auth-the-presenter when discussing the unsigned-ness of ClaimDescriptionTbs in the context of an attestation request.

- Consistent use of 'cannot' vs 'can not'

- "An implementer might desire to select multiple cryptographic keys based on a shared attribute or similar schemes." - the section does not describe 'similar schemes', so that can be dropped.

- "An Attester MUST omit including" --> "An Attester MUST NOT include"

- "Presenter or Reciever or Recipient" - this spec does not define the latter two terms. Replaced with "Verifier"

- Moved discussion around including a request ClaimDescriptionTbs within a signed PkixEvidence from sec-cons-privacy to sec-cons-auth-the-presenter.
